newsitem.title: USA: Rain helps Oklahoma HRW wheat crop development.
newsitem.headline: Rain helps Oklahoma HRW wheat crop development.

text.p: Rain aided development of Oklahoma's winter wheat crop in the week ended Sunday and harvest could start as early as this week in far southwestern counties, the state's agricultural statistics service said.
Up to five inches of rain fell during the week, lifting soil moisture levels to nine percent short, 79 percent adequate and 12 percent surplus.
Wheat was rated 11 percent very poor, 16 percent poor, 36 percent fair, 36 percent good and one percent excellent.
The crop was 98 percent headed, versus 93 percent average, and 33 percent had reached the dough stage, versus 52 average.
"Harvest has not yet begun in Oklahoma but custom combiners are expected to start later this week in Tillman County," the report said.
Corn was 96 percent planted, against 98 average. Soybeans were 56 percent planted, ahead of 37 percent average.
Sorghum plantings were two weeks behind average pace with nine percent seeded, versus 40 percent last year and 33 percent average.
Pasture and range conditions were rated nil very poor, two percent poor, 20 percent fair, 71 percent good and seven percent excellent.
